steps.text: Study materials for certification obtained from Arkansas State Plant Board.
Obtain study materials from University of Arkansas Cooperative Extension Service, pesticide labels, and manufacturers.
Contact Arkansas State Plant Board for examinations.
Prepare for general standards and Classification 7 exams.
Construct buildings in food processing facilities with preventive design and maintenance.
Maintain daily pest management programs.
Address pests from facility and surrounding areas.
Follow federal and state regulations.
Implement proper engineering design.
Maintain short grass and trimmed shrubs.
Install paved access and proper drainage.
Create an 18- to 24-inch gravel strip around foundation.
Place night-lights at least 30 feet away from doors.
Keep framing at least four inches from walls.
Fill necessary voids with materials like polyurethane foam.
Install concrete or coated concrete floors.
Use acid-proof or brick floors for wet processing areas.
Seal and clean wall materials.
Prevent hollow panel-type walls from becoming insect quarters.
Install smooth and free of standing water roofs.
Use as few windows as possible with good options.
Install metal and tight-fitting doors.
Install air curtains at large doors.
Use dust-tight fixtures for good lighting.
Install electrical and plumbing services for easy access and cleaning.
Eliminate litter, waste, and uncut grass. Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns. Ensure proper drainage. Position lighting away from buildings.
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps. Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs.
(Rodents) Maintain bait stations. (Insects) Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites. (Birds) Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate.
Rodent-proof all openings. Screen windows. Eliminate cracks, crevices, and ledges. Block bird access to ledges.
Keep all areas free of loose materials. Clean structures and equipment frequently.
Use electrified grids inside for insect attraction.
Inspect all incoming vehicles and materials.
Store materials away from walls for inspection access.
Use rodent bait stations where policy permits.
Use space treatments with nonresiduals, crack and crevice treatments with residuals, spot treatments, and fumigation for raw commodities.
Implement a detailed monitoring program and a total facility IPM program.
Use rodent traps near doors if needed.
Form an inspection committee.
Compile a list of deficiencies.
Thoroughly inspect all areas.
Record and distribute notes.
Departments correct defects.
Committee reviews and assign dates.
Inspect suspect areas using a flashlight.
Spread out stock on a flat surface and observe for movement.
Inspect areas most likely to produce results, such as under and inside equipment.
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices.
Consider periodic inspections by an outside firm.
Inspect stored product regularly.
Use visual inspection as a key method.
Minimize insect movement by inspecting incoming materials.
Use pheromone-baited traps for inspecting bagged commodities.
Determine the extent of a problem based on trap catches.
Use pheromone traps for monitoring and interception.
Place traps on facility perimeter.
Adjust trap placement based on temperature gradients.
Inspect traps regularly and interpret catches.
Read label information printed on pesticide container.
Apply pesticides according to label instructions.
Ensure application in food-handling establishments adheres to regulations.
Identify life cycles of beetles and moths: egg, larva, pupa, adult.
Understand beetle larvae have no legs on the back half of their body.
Recognize moth larvae have legs on the back half of their body.
Inspect food products for moths and beetles.

Identify specific pests: almond moth, Indianmeal moth, Mediterranean Flour Moth, mealmoth, lesser grain borers, cigarette beetles, drugstore beetles, confused flour beetles, sawtoothed grain beetles, merchant grain beetles, or foreign grain beetles.
Implement control measures: avoidance, sanitation, heat treatment, cold treatment, residual insecticides, space sprays, fumigation, or a combination.
Identify pests: Spider Beetles, Warehouse Beetle / Dermestid Beetles, Cockroaches, Flies, Ants, Bees and Wasps, Booklice.
Determine pest characteristics: appearance, behavior, preferred environments.
Implement control measures based on pest and environment.
Monitor for signs of infestation or reinfestation.
Identify rodent signs such as droppings, runways, rubmarks, burrows, tracks, and urine.
Implement sanitation and habitat modification to reduce rodent presence.
Rodent-proof construction by sealing openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats.
Use compressed air sprayer for crack and crevice, spot, and general sprays.
Apply using compressed air sprayer in pest control.
Clean mp after each use.
Check gaskets and valves regularly.
Never leave pressurized equipment unattended.
Determine nozzle type for spray pattern.
Maintain dusters by keeping them clean and dry.
Use appropriate equipment for space treating.
Wear respirators as indicated on the label.
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks.
Wash respirators regularly.
Store respirators in a clean, protected place.

constraints.text: Require an 18-inch space between pallets and walls for inspection.
A written inspection procedure for incoming raw products is required by law.
Use pheromone-baited traps for identifying pests.
Monitor pests on facility perimeter to prevent indoor infestations.
Adjust trap placement based on temperature changes.
Follow federal and state pesticide regulations.
Ensure proper application of pesticides based on pesticide labels and site groups.
Avoid using residuals in production areas where they might be carried into the area.
Check for signs of infestation: webbing, silken threads, damaged packaging, or presence of larvae and adults.
Ensure proper storage conditions to prevent infestations: low moisture levels, cool temperatures, and good ventilation.
Ensure proper pest identification before implementing control measures.
Maintain cleanliness to prevent pest infestations.
Understand rodent behavior, including their senses, reactions, and agility.
Clean facilities to eliminate food, water, and shelter for rodents.
Safety precautions: Proper maintenance, regular checks, and never leaving pressurized equipment unattended.
